person.name: Ellie Pavlick
person.description: Proud advisor of the below students. :)

person.name: Dylan Ebert
person.description: I work on grounded language representations: getting computers to understand language in the context of the world, like people do. I'm also more broadly interested in NLP, AI, HCI, CogSci, and game/web development.

person.name: Charlie Lovering
person.description: Representation learning, generalization/robustness, reinforcement learning, multiagent communication

person.name: Roma Patel
person.description: My research involves using natural language to structure reinforcement learning problems with the aim of building intelligent, interpretable and ethical agents that make use of language information to solve tasks. I'm also generally interested in understanding the biases learned and exhibited by neural models, to allow us to build more ethical and less (harmfully) biased systems interpretable by language-users i.e., us humans.

person.name: Aaron Traylor
person.description: Logical inference, neuro-symbolic reasoning, few-shot learning, generalization

person.name: Albert Webson
person.description: My research seeks to answer the ambitious but inescapable question of “What does it take for a computer to genuinely understand language?” Currently, I’m working on an interdisciplinary theory of semantic meaning (linguistics), conceptual development (cognitive science), and mental representation (philosophy); plus, of course, how do they inform what types of grounding, structure, and evaluation we should have for NLP models.

person.name: Sydney Zink
person.description: My research is interested in language documentation and community tracing, particularly with regard to low-resource and minority languages within contexts. Related interests include dialectical evolution with relation to theory of mind, as well as adversarial multilingual settings, e.g. manipulable translation systems and speaker identification aversion for a particular language.

person.name: Jack Merullo
person.description: Grounded language learning, representation learning, few-shot learning, information retrieval
